What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Interesting to look at the famous incompleteness theorems from a different perspective.

This class is basically a semester long preparation for Gdels incompleteness theorems. Along the way, you learn about the concept of computability, which I thought was very interesting. For someone who is interested in completeness, this class is a must take.
My understanding of theorems and computability as a concept has improved dramatically
Studied the proofs for Godel's Incompleteness Theorems.
I got a general idea of what the incompleteness theorems are and how they work, which was interesting.

LITERALLY NOTHING. To be honest this class was incredibly useless. The only things you really learn about are: Turing machines (which you learn in CS 201) so really the only #NEW# thing is abacus machines. We spent almost the entire semester on those two topics, at the end of the semester we talked about the "logic" part, which was so rushed that none of it really got into our brain. For instance, we barely covered the incompleteness theorems, which was supposed to be the main thing this class covered.
Learnt a lot about logic.
Godel's incompleteness theorems, notion of computability
So much about logic and computability! The course was great and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I learned how to reason better about logic and, even better, what cannot even be reasoned about.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It felt that while we eventually got to our goal of proving the incompleteness theorems, such a proof doesn't need a whole semester of build up, or it if does, we should have explored more interesting ideas that logicians have thought of along the way. It felt like a lot of beautiful ideas went undiscussed, and that we were so focused on the incompleteness theorems that a lot of mathematical logic was skipped over.
Strength of the course is in uniqueness of material and great teaching.
Interesting material.

The course is very laid back and the professor teaches the ideas in class well. The final is almost impossible, though, in that it expects you to come up with proofs using techniques barely mentioned in class. I wish the course was more rigorous, since at its current pace you don't really learn enough to understand the cool stuff at the end, so you mostly come away with a few specific facts and some vague understandings.

STRENGTHS:  The Prof is nice, she is a wonderful person and she would even meet with you on weekends if you needed help . 
WEAKNESS: The prof is horrible at teaching, if you have no background on this type of stuff then reading the book is basically out of the table, and reading the lectures notes is simply just a waste of time.  To succeed in this class you would probably need recorded lectures, or a bunch of time to read the lecture notes until you understand them.
Great course taught by Prof Shin! It was absolutely wonderful!

A strength is how understanding, patient, and dedicated the professor is. She was available at any hour to reply to emails and questions and, during the era of zoom lectures, was willing to call at any time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: not much.
Format worked well
The professor was very responsive to meetings.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely.

Not really, I felt that the lectures were often unclear to understand, and I often relied on my mathematical logic background to fill in gaps in the lectures. I would only recommend it to someone for the wide array of reqs it satisfies, QR + Hu + CS Elective.
Yes, the professor is amazing and super kind. The material is also super interesting. The assignments really help facilitate learning without being too much or too stressful.
Absolutely, a great way to learn some math theory
I would absolutely recommend this course! Logic with Prof. Shin is a pleasure.
Yes, the professor is clearly very knowledgeable on the subject and the class was pretty enjoyable.
The professor is really passionate about the material, so if you're really into logic maybe you'll enjoy it. If you're coming from a math or CS background, it might feel a little boring.

THIS CLASS IS NOT A GUT.  Many people ( including me)  that come from the math major take this class  because they think it is a gut, since this is what is generally believed. THIS IS NOT TRUE, this is what they don't tell you:  The exams are HARD AF, yes this course is a gut in terms of workload, but this is not a good thing because it does not prepare you for the brutal final and oral exams. I have taken some of the hardest math classes at yale ( 350, 305 ,310,...) and I still thought the final was simply brutal, but this is all because we never learned the material properly in the first place because of how little homework there was. The week before the oral exam I pulled a couple all-nighterS just trying to read the book(which is also impossible to read)   and watch the lectures at least twice because of how bad they were. I had no background on logic or any of this kind of material, so I, along with some of my friends with the same background, found this class really hard towards the end of the semester. I WOULD ONLY RECOMMEND this class if you have some sort of experience, otherwise it almost better if you simply stay away.
I would definitely recommend it if you are interested in logic at all!
Yes, absolutely! Professor Shin teaches an amazing course and the content is very very interesting!
